level.heading: Definitions.
level.text: For the purposes of §§ 4-205.62 through 4-205.68, the term:
"Board" means the District of Columbia Board of Education.
"Ceased to attend school" means a pregnant or parenting teen has 20 or more consecutive full days of unexcused absences from school.
"Child care" means care, supervision, and guidance for children for less than 24 hours per day per child in any licensed child development facility.
"Department" means the Department of Human Services.
"Dropout" means a pregnant or parenting teen who has:
Has not graduated from high school or received a general educational equivalency diploma or certificate of completion from an alternative course of study approved by the Board; and
Does not meet the school attendance requirements of § 4-205.65.
"High school equivalency diploma" means a certificate of educational achievement issued under the regulations and requirements of the District of Columbia Public Schools.
"Pregnant or parenting teen" means a person who has a child or children, or is pregnant in the third trimester of the first pregnancy, and is under 18 years of age.

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 11-72
level.text: Law 11-72, the "Public Assistance Self-Sufficiency Program Amendment Act of 1995," was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 11-62, which was referred to the Committee on Human Services. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on June 6, 1995, and July 29, 1995, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on August 16, 1995, it was assigned Act No. 11-139 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 11-72 became effective on October 27, 1995.

level.heading: Expiration of law Expiration of Law 11-72
